return std::max(std::max(std::abs(this->data[0]), std::abs(this->data[1])),

Just one last thing, could you reduce this line to have less than 80 chars? If you run the code checker, it will show you the errors:

```
$ bash tools/code_check.sh 
./include/ignition/math/Vector3.hh:316:  Lines should very rarely be longer than 100 characters  [whitespace/line_length] [4]
./include/ignition/math/Vector3.hh:323:  Lines should very rarely be longer than 100 characters  [whitespace/line_length] [4]
Total errors found: 2
```

content.raw:
Have you considered an implementation that doesn't use `Min()` and `Max()`? Something like:

`std::max(std::max(std::abs(this->data[0]), std::abs(this->data[1])), std::abs(this->data[2]));`

I think that should take slightly less operations.
content.html:
Have you considered an implementation that doesn't use Min() and Max()? Something like:

std::max(std::max(std::abs(this->data[0]), std::abs(this->data[1])), std::abs(this->data[2]));

I think that should take slightly less operations.

content.raw: Do you set the CMake flag `-DBUILD_TESTING=ON`? That should make sure tests are actually built. If they’re not built, they cannot be run. However, it is important if you saw the two tests you wrote being run and succeed.
content.html: Do you set the CMake flag -DBUILD_TESTING=ON? That should make sure tests are actually built. If they’re not built, they cannot be run. However, it is important if you saw the two tests you wrote being run and succeed.
